metadata.title: Mechanistic exploration of CpRe(CO)<ce:inf loc=post>3</ce:inf>-catalyzed coupling of chloromethyloxirane with CO<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf>: Unexpected potentials of CO ligands

Scheme 1 Typical reaction pattern for transition-metal catalyzed CO2/epoxide coupling reaction [26]. [M] represents the metal complex. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 The Re(CO)5Br-, CpRe(CO)3-catalyzedcouplings of chloromethyloxirane with CO2 reported by Hua et al. [27]. Scheme 2 Scheme 3 The mechanism on the Re(CO)5Br--catalyzed couplings of chloromethyloxirane (R) with CO2 theoretically reported by Wu’s group [25]. Scheme 3 Scheme 4 HOMOs and NBO charges calculated for three CO2 insertion transition states, TS9-10 , TS6-7 and TS2-3 . The bond lengths and energies are given in Å, kcal/mol, respectively. Scheme 4 Scheme 5 Sketch of the catalytic cycle for the P formation from CpRe(CO)3-catalyzed couplings of chloromethyloxirane (R) with CO2 based on the present calculations. Scheme 5 Fig. 1 Calculated free energy profile for forming product P based on the proposal of the Hua’s group [27]. The relative free energies are given in kcal/mol. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Optimized geometries with selected structural parameters for the species shown in Fig. 1. The hydrogen atoms on the Cp ring are not shown for clarity. The bond lengths are given in Å. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Calculated free energy profile for the 2 → 3 transformation along Path a established in the present work. The relative free energies are given in kcal/mol. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Optimized geometries with selected structural parameters for the species shown in Fig. 3. The hydrogen atoms on the Cp ring are not shown for clarity. The bond lengths are given in Å. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Calculated free energy profile for the 2 → 3 transformation along Path b based on the proposal of Wu and co-workers. The relative free energies are given in kcal/mol. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Optimized geometries with selected structural parameters for the species shown in Fig. 5. The hydrogen atoms on the Cp ring are not shown for clarity. The bond lengths are given in Å. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Calculated free energy profiles for forming the product P from intermediate 3. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Optimized geometries with selected structural parameters for the species shown in Fig. 7. The hydrogen atoms on the Cp ring are not shown for clarity. The bond lengths are given in Å. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Relative free energies for TS8-p , TS12-p and TS3-4 with selected structural parameters involved. The bond lengths are given in Å. Fig. 9 Mechanistic exploration of CpRe(CO)3-catalyzed coupling of chloromethyloxirane with CO2: Unexpected potentials of CO ligands Yuxia Liu a b ⁎ Guojing Pei b Jiayong Wang b Lingjun Liu b Dongju Zhang a ⁎⁎ Siwei Bi b ⁎⁎ a Key Lab of Colloid and Interface Chemistry, Ministry of Education, Institute of Theoretical Chemistry, Shandong University, Jinan, 250100, PR China Key Lab of Colloid and Interface Chemistry Ministry of Education Institute of Theoretical Chemistry Shandong University Jinan 250100 PR China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Qufu Normal University, Qufu 273165, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Qufu Normal University Qufu 273165 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Key Lab of Colloid and Interface Chemistry, Ministry of Education, Institute of Theoretical Chemistry, Shandong University, Jinan, 250100, PR China. Key Lab of Colloid and Interface Chemistry Ministry of Education Institute of Theoretical Chemistry Shandong University Jinan 250100 PR China ⁎⁎ Corresponding authors. Key Lab of Colloid and Interface Chemistry Ministry of Education Institute of Theoretical Chemistry Shandong University Jinan 250100 PR China Graphical abstract Density functional theory (DFT) calculations have been performed to unravel the detailed mechanism of the CpRe(CO)3-catalyzed coupling reaction of CO2 with chloromethyloxirane (R). The mechanisms proposed in previous literature have been examined. However, the computed results seem not to completely rationalize the experimental findings. Alternatively, by performing an exhaustive search on the potential energy surface, we presented a novel CO-assisted mechanism, which provides an effective access to the catalytic coupling. The newly established mechanism involves the CO bond cleavage of R from the less hindered side, release of one CO ligand, CO2 insertion, re-coordination of the dissociated CO ligand, another CO ligand shift, reductive elimination with simultaneous migration of carbonyl substituent, resulting in P and regeneration of CpRe(CO)2. Two CO ligands attached to CpRe(CO)2 play significant roles in lowering the key CO2 insertion and reductive elimination: (i) One CO ligand dissociation prior to CO2 insertion contributes to reduce the electron density on the Re metal, facilitating the CO2 O atom nucleophilic attack. (ii) After performing the migration, another initially inactive CO ligand serves as a carbonyl substituent, which lowers the energy penalty for later reductive elimination through the resultant extra π-interaction and the smaller ring tension energy involved in TS. The theoretical results provide insight into the mechanism of the important coupling reaction and rationalize well the experimental observations. Keywords CpRe(CO)3 CO2 Chloromethyloxirane CO DFT 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2), as cheap, nontoxic and renewable C1 building block, has attracted much attention for the syntheses of versatile valuable chemicals from the standpoint of environmental protection and resource utilization [1–8]. One of the most promising methodologies in this area is metal-catalyzed coupling of epoxides and CO2 to synthesize five-membered cyclic carbonates [9], which are widely utilized as excellent aprotic polar solvents, electrolytes in lithium-ion batteries, fine chemical intermediates, and raw materials for the preparations of polymers and engineering plastic, etc. [10,11]. Up to date, a wide variety of metal catalysts are developed to facilitate the CO2/epoxide coupling reactions [1–8], including organometallic complexes [12], metal halides [13–15], bimetallic complexes [16], and bifunctional metallic complexes [17–19]. Following the experimental studies, a number of theoretical studies are performed [13,16,17,20–25], which are expected to shed light on the underlying catalytic reaction mechanisms and to help the development of more powerful catalysts. It is known that the transition-metal catalyzed CO2/epoxide coupling reactions normally involve three elementary steps with no special assistance (Scheme 1 ) [26,27]: the cleavage of the less hindered CO bond, CO2 insertion into the metal-O bond, and the reductive elimination, leading to the cyclic carbonate product with the catalyst regeneration. Recently, the Rhenium(I) complexes are experimentally introduced by Hua’s group to catalyze the CO2/epoxide coupling reaction under solvent-free conditions [27]. Intriguingly, as indicated in Scheme 2 , both Re(CO)5Br and CpRe(CO)3 exhibit a high catalytic efficiency at 110 °C for the coupling between CO2 and chloromethyloxirane (R) to afford the cyclic carbonate (P) in 97% and 91% yield, respectively. The Re(CO)5Br-catalyzed reaction mechanism has been contributed theoretically by Wu et al. [25] (Scheme 3 ), in which the release of one CO ligand is required for subsequent CO2 insertion process (A → B). After the reductive elimination (B → C), the dissociated CO ligand re-coordinates to the metal center, regenerating the active catalyst Re(CO)4Br (C → P). Note that CO ligands are also involved in the CpRe(CO)3 catalyst. In this paper, with aid of density functional theory (DFT) calculations, we are interested in studying the detailed mechanisms for the CpRe(CO)3-catalyzed coupling reaction (in Scheme 2), from which we expected to uncover i) whether the typical pattern mentioned in Scheme 1 and Wu’s mechanism in Scheme 3 is reasonable for explaining the experimental results, ii) If not, what the available mechanism should be, and iii) what the roles of the CO ligands are. It is anticipated that answers to these issues would deepen the understanding for the significant reaction and further promote the development of new related catalytic reactions. 2 Computational details Molecular geometries of all the complexes were optimized without constraints via DFT calculations using the Becke3LYP (B3LYP) [29–32] functional, which has been shown to be appropriate for studying rhenium complexes systems in a lot of recent literature [33–36]. Frequency calculations at the same level of theory have also been performed to identify all stationary points as minima (zero imaginary frequencies) or transition states (one imaginary frequency). To obtain the thermodynamic data at 383.15 K and 60 atm, the ReadIsotopes parameter associated with the highest isotopes of each element in vibrational frequency calculations is used to correct the influence of thermal energy on the total energy. Intrinsic reaction coordinates (IRC) [37,38] were calculated for the transition states to confirm that such structures indeed connect two relevant minima. The 6–31G(d, p) basis set [39–42] was used for C, H, Cl and O atoms while the effective core potentials (ECPs) of Hay and Wadt with a double-valence basis set (LanL2DZ) [43–45] were used to describe the transition metal rhenium atom. To take into account solvent effects, single-point energies calculations at the same DFT level were performed on the geometries obtained in the gas phase by employing the simple self-consistent reaction field (SCRF) method based on the Dipole model. A GEPOL cavity with an average area of the tesserae of 0.4 Å has been employed in all calculations [46]. Corresponding to the experimental conditions, scCO2 was used as the solvent with the dielectric constant ε = 1.49 and density ρ = 0.817 g cm−3 [47]. The computational method employed in this work is nearly the same as the one used in Ref. [25]. And all thermodynamic data presented in this paper were calculated under the actual reaction temperature of 383.15 k and atmosphere pressure of 60 atm. All the optimization calculations in the gas phase were implemented employing the Gaussian 03 software package [48], while the single-point solvent calculations were performed with the Gaussian 09 version [49]. In the following discussion, relative free energies were exclusively employed to analyze the reaction mechanism. It should be pointed out here that the entropic contribution to free energies based on the gas-phase calculations is remarkably exaggerated for association/dissociation transformations relative to the situation in solution. In order to obtain more accurate free energies in solution, in this paper, we corrected the free energies by employing the method developed by Pratt et al. [50], in which an additional 4.3 kcal/mol free-energy correction can be applied to each component change (i.e., a reaction from m to n components has an additional free-energy correction of (n-m) × 4.3 kcal/mol) during the reaction. Previous literature have demonstrated that such a correction is reasonable and efficient [51–55]. 3 Results and discussion In the CpRe(CO)3-catalyzed coupling reaction, initially, the decarbonylation of CpRe(CO)3 gives CpRe(CO)2, which behaves as the active catalyst and also is considered as the reference point in the whole reaction mechanism. The analogous case can be found in the Re(CO)5Br-catlayzed [25,27] and HCo(CO)4-included systems [56]. In this section, the detailed mechanisms initiated by the CO bond cleavage of R from the less hindered side are presented due to lower energy barriers involved, while those results starting from the more hindered side are collected in Figs. S2–S5 in the Supporting Information. 3.1 Normally considered coupling mechanism We firstly examined the reaction pattern shown in Scheme 1 . Fig. 1 collects the calculated free energy profile with schematic geometries of stationary points located, and the corresponding optimized geometries with selected structural parameters are given in Fig. 2 . At the entrance of the reaction, the active catalyst, CpRe(CO)2, σ-coordinates with the O1 atom of R to form adduct 1. This step is significantly exergonic by 13.1 kcal/mol. From 1, the C2O1 bond cleavage through oxidative addition produces the four-membered-ring Re(III) complex 2 with a barrier of 25.4 kcal/mol. And then, CO2 inserts into ReO1 bond via TS2-3 affording six-membered cyclorhenium intermediate 3, which follows the reductive elimination, through TS3-4 , to furnish P and re-generate Cp(CO)2Re. It is found that the energy requirement for the direct CO2 insertion is 43.7 kcal/mol, corresponding to the difference between TS2-3 and 2. And the direct reductive elimination step via TS3-4 has a barrier of even as high as 53.3 kcal/mol relative to 2. Clearly, neither of the two steps is workable under given conditions. 3.2 Alternative CO2 insertion pathways To reveal how the CO2 inserts into the ReO1 bond (2 → 3), we initially designed an alternative mechanism, denoted as Path a, which features the migration of one CO ligand in 2. Fig. 3 presents the calculated energy profile with schematic geometries of stationary points located, and the corresponding geometries with selected structural parameters are shown in Fig. 4 . As exhibited in Fig. 3, complex 2 performs the adjacent C(CO) migration to C2 atom and gets the ring-expanding intermediate 5, in which the migrated CO ligand serves as a carbonyl substituent. From 5, the CO2 insertion into ReO bond gives a more stable cyclorhenium species 7 with O1 → Re coordination. The insertion transition state is denoted as TS6-7 and leads to a barrier of 25.6 kcal/mol relative to 5. In the next step, a structural isomerization results in the seven-membered metallocycle 8, which is found to be a metastable structure because of its 16-electron configuration. Subsequent conversion from 8 to 3 is related to the recovery of the carbonyl substituent to be CO ligand through the carbonyl C shift. Along Path a shown in Fig. 3, it is seen that, although the rate-determining CO2 insertion step has an activation barrier of 25.6 kcal/mol (the difference between TS6-7 and 5), which, regrettably, leads to extremely high overall barrier (45.9 kcal/mol relative to 2). Different from the direct CO2 insertion process (2 → 3) in Fig. 1, an alternative mechanism featuring decarbonylation prior to the CO2 insertion is also considered to generate 3. The denoted Path b is displayed in Fig. 5 , which is similar to the Re(CO)4Br-catalyzed system reported by Wu et al. [25]. Starting from 2, dissociation of one CO ligand followed by CO2 insertion provides the species 3 after re-coordination of the dissociated CO ligand. The overall barrier along the pathway is computed to be 39.3 kcal/mol, corresponding to the difference between TS11-3 and 2, which is much lower than 53.3 kcal/mol in Fig. 1 and 45.9 kcal/mol in Fig. 3, respectively. Note that the barrier value of 39.3 kcal/mol remains high. It is speculated that the calculations might have been overestimated due to the gases involved. Herein, we are interested in the comparison of three possible pathways. Thus the relative barrier values become more important relative to the absolute barriers. Similar case can be found in the Ru-Mn involved system reported by Lau and Lin [16]. The above discussions provide detailed mechanisms for three possible CO2 insertion pathways starting from the global minimum 2. For convenient comparison, three competitive CO2 insertion transition states, TS9-10 (insertion after one CO ligand dissociation), TS2-3 (direct insertion) and TS6-7 (CO ligand-assisted insertion), are collected in Scheme 4 . Firstly, we plotted the highest occupied molecular orbitals (HOMOs) calculated for the three transition states. It is seen in Scheme 4 that, in TS9-10 , a large orbital overlap is presented in between O1 and C3 atom, which contributes significantly to the structural stability. In contrast, there is relatively smaller orbital overlap in TS6-7 and even no such orbital interaction in TS2-3 . By performing natural bond orbital (NBO) analyses, we found that the charge on Re and O2 atom in TS9-10 is −0.03 and −0.52 e, while it is −0.42 and −0.67 e in TS2-3 , respectively. It is apparent that, after one CO ligand dissociation, the reduced electron density on the metal center remarkably promotes the CO2 insertion via TS9-10 due to the stronger electrostatic attraction between the two atoms involved. In addition, the Re⋯O1 distance in TS9-10 , 2.064 Å, is much shorter than 2.548 Å in TS2-3 , implying the former transition state is earlier than the latter one. Thus, it is not surprising that TS9-10 is more stable in energy than TS2-3 . On the other hand, in TS6-7 , the Re⋯O3 interaction enables the trans Re⋯O2 interaction much weaker, which thereby brings the energy penalty for the Re⋯O2 bonding. We can clearly see that the Re⋯O2 distance (2.732 Å) in TS6-7 is remarkably longer than that (2.278 Å, Fig. 6 ) in TS9-10 . Overall, TS9-10 is expected to be energetically much more favored than TS6-7 and TS2-3 . 3.3 Alternative reductive elimination pathways Next, we focus our attention to the 3 → P transformation. The direct reductive elimination (Fig. 1) and reductive elimination after one CO ligand dissociation (Fig. S1 in Supporting Information) have been theoretically examined, both which, unsatisfyingly, involve substantially high energy demand. Here, we propose an alternative mechanism, in which the initially inactive C(4)O ligand participates into the reaction and undergoes a role switching: a formal ligand → carbonyl substituent → formal ligand. As exhibited in Fig. 7 , the C(4) in 3 transfers to C2 atom and affords the ring-expanded seven-cyclic intermediate 8, in which the C(4)O ligand becomes a substituent. The migration step via TS3-8 is endergonic by 14.7 kcal/mol with a barrier of 20.4 kcal/mol. And then the O2⋯C2 linkage with simultaneous C4 migration back to the Rh center results in product P and regeneration of Cp(CO)2Re. The concerted step via TS8-p is facile and has a barrier of only 3.9 kcal/mol. Starting from 8, alternatively, the C(4)O ligand is firstly released to give 12, from which the O2⋯C2 bonding with synchronous C4 shift generates the product P and regenerates Cp(CO)3Re. However, the highest stationary point TS12-p along the alternative route is 4.3 kcal/mol higher in free energy than TS8-p . Therefore, the one-step conversion from 8 to P is kinetically much more favorable (Fig. 8 ). Note that in Fig. 7, TS8-p (3.4 kcal/mol) is 23.9 kcal/mol lower in free energy than TS3-4 in Fig. 1 (27.3 kcal/mol). The large energy difference, as displayed in Fig. 9 , can be divided into two parts: 19.4 kcal/mol (the difference between TS3-4 and TS12-P ) and 4.5 kcal/mol (the difference between TS12-P and TS8-P ). By comparing the geometries of TS3-4 and TS12-p , it is found that the energy penalty of 19.4 kcal/mol comes from two parts: one is ring tension energy (three-membered ring in TS3-4 & four-membered ring in TS12-p ). As compared to TS3-4 , the O2C2 bonding in TS12-p is accompanied by the C4 migration from C2 (as CO substituent with ReC4 σ interaction) to Re center (as CO ligand with ReC4 σ-π interaction). Thus, the lacking of additional π-interaction in TS3-4 is another important contributor for the 19.4 kcal/mol energy. As far as the 4.5 kcal/mol energy cost is concerned, that TS8-p is earlier than TS12-p should be the main responsibility, as evidenced by the C4⋯C2 distances involved, 1.711 and 1.921 Å, respectively. 3.4 Understanding the roles of CO ligands On the basis of the calculated results above, we schematically show the catalytic cycles for the coupling between CO2 and R in Scheme 5 , which provides a detailed and consistent view of the mechanism details of the significant catalytic coupling. Two CO ligands attached to the Re atom exhibit excellent performance for promoting the reaction as following: 1) After oxidative addition (R → 2), the dissociation of one CO ligand prior to the CO2 insertion lowers the electron density on the metal center, which, thereby, facilitates the subsequent CO2 insertion (2 → 9 →10). 2) After re-coordination of the dissociated CO ligand, another initially no-reactive C(4)O ligand behaves as a carbonyl substituent (3 → 8) by the C4 insertion into ReC2 bond. The following simultaneous migration of the carbonyl substituent greatly promotes the reductive elimination (8 → P) due to the extra stabilized π-interaction as well as the resultant less-strained ring involved in TS. Overall, two CO ligands in active catalyst, CpRe(CO)2, are essential for ensuring the CpRe(CO)3-catalyzed coupling reaction under the given experimental conditions. 4 Conclusions The detailed mechanisms for CpRe(CO)3-catalyzed couplings of CO2 with chloromethyloxirane (R) have been systematically investigated with aid of DFT calculations. The computational results indicate that the possible pathways proposed in early literature cannot completely explain the observed cyclic carbonate product (P) due to high barriers involved. Alternatively, a novel reaction mechanism, which features the assistance of CO ligands, provides the most efficient access to the significant coupling. In the newly proposed mechanism, the following steps are proposed: the oxidative addition of the CO bond in R from the less hindered side (R → 2), release of one CO ligand (2 → 9), CO2 insertion (9 → 10), re-coordination of the dissociated CO ligand (10 → 3), migration of another CO ligand (3 → 8), reductive elimination with simultaneous migration of carbonyl substituent and regeneration of CpRe(CO)2 (8 → P). The presence of two CO ligands are necessary for the occurrence of the reaction under given conditions. On one hand, dissociation of one CO ligand prior to CO2 insertion could reduce the electron density on the metal, making more easily subsequent CO2 insertion. On the other hand, after the migration, another initially inactive CO ligand behaves as a carbonyl substituent, which significantly contributes to later reductive elimination due to the resultant extra π-interaction and the less-strained ring involved in TS. The present theoretical results provide deepen insight into the mechanistic details for the significant coupling reaction, which is expected to be informative for the efficient design of new catalytic CO2/epoxide couplings. Acknowledgments We gratefully acknowledge Prof. Zhenyang Lin at Hong Kong University of Science and Technology for helpful discussions. This work was jointly supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Nos. 21433006 and 21473100), Opening Foundation of Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Detection Technology for Tumor Markers (KLDTTM2015-9), and the Doctoral Start-Up Scientific Research Foundation of Qufu Normal University (Grant No. BSQD2012018). Appendix A Supplementary data Figures giving the calculated free energy profiles along other possible pathways for the formation of product P and Cartesian coordinates for all the species involved in the reaction. Supplementary material related to this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.mcat.2018.08.001. coredata.dc:description: Density functional theory (DFT) calculations have been performed to unravel the detailed mechanism of the CpRe(CO)3-catalyzed coupling reaction of CO2 with chloromethyloxirane (R). The mechanisms proposed in previous literature have been examined. However, the computed results seem not to completely rationalize the experimental findings. Alternatively, by performing an exhaustive search on the potential energy surface, we presented a novel CO-assisted mechanism, which provides an effective access to the catalytic coupling. The newly established mechanism involves the CO bond cleavage of R from the less hindered side, release of one CO ligand, CO2 insertion, re-coordination of the dissociated CO ligand, another CO ligand shift, reductive elimination with simultaneous migration of carbonyl substituent, resulting in P and regeneration of CpRe(CO)2. Two CO ligands attached to CpRe(CO)2 play significant roles in lowering the key CO2 insertion and reductive elimination: (i) One CO ligand dissociation prior to CO2 insertion contributes to reduce the electron density on the Re metal, facilitating the CO2 O atom nucleophilic attack. (ii) After performing the migration, another initially inactive CO ligand serves as a carbonyl substituent, which lowers the energy penalty for later reductive elimination through the resultant extra π-interaction and the smaller ring tension energy involved in TS. The theoretical results provide insight into the mechanism of the important coupling reaction and rationalize well the experimental observations.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanistic exploration of CpRe(CO)3-catalyzed coupling of chloromethyloxirane with CO2: Unexpected potentials of CO ligands
